Fields.DialogueText: Ah, I see you've taken a liking to my sextant.
Oui. C'est manifique. I've never seen one like this.
Neither have I. It releases the clamp from that little button there...
Here? Oh, I see. The bronze is admirable... not tarnished in the least.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I do my best to care for it. But a little patina won't hurt it... it would give it some character, wouldn't you say?
Fortunately, its case keeps it well-protected. But if the sextant does begin to color, its effectiveness won't be impacted.
I see to the bronze regularly. Of course, it wouldn't be the end of the world were it to gracefully age, but I prefer the look of polished bronze.

Fields.DialogueText: I agree, sir. Upon further inspection, though... this is actually a quintant, isn't it?
I concur, Capitaine. Hmm... from further inspection, I believe it is safe to assume that I am holding a quintant. It's arc measures an additional 54 degrees to that of a regular sextant.
It is quite stunning, as it is now. But this is not a regular sextant is it, Capitaine? A quintant, perhaps?
I was wondering if you'd notice that, Léopard. It *is* a quintant.
Speaking of time... we have company.
*ALARM*
Then we'd better get on our way.
@BATTLE
... Capitaine? I was thinking, if it weren't trouble, I'd like one of my own... a sextant.
You can use mine any time, Léopard. It's not a problem.
Oh, I know!  It's just that I wouldn't want to accidentally drop it. It would be best to have two on hand, wouldn't you agree? Just in case?
You have a point. Sure, I don't see why not.
Merci, Capitaine!
The arc has a 144-degree range and can calculate longitude without the use of a chronometer. Useful in times like these.
Dépêchez-vous! Get to your stations!
@BATTLE
Léopard, the crew was a bit sluggish out there... did you happen to catch that?
Non. It isn't my drills. I spoke to a few comrades and there has been chatter about their sleeping conditions...
But the crew is sleeping poorly?
I agree with you wholeheartedly, Capitaine. And it's not just sleeplessness - apparently the bunks are inspiring nausea, sinus irritation, and a whole host of other ongoing medical concerns.
You'll recall that we passed through a particularly foul-smelling batch of Morgana mist a few days back?
I'm not likely to forget it.
Apparently the stench is lingering in the crew's bedding, sir. Not the sheets - those have been thoroughly cleaned - but the bunks themselves.
Yeah. It's there in my quarters too.
And are you having trouble sleeping as well?

Fields.MenuText: By the time I lie down I'm too tired to notice.
I'm getting by.
I haven't slept a full night since the war started. This isn't making any difference at all.

Fields.DialogueText: Okay, that's something we need to address. Our funds may be limited, but a sleepless crew won't do the war effort any good.
Right. We need new bunks, then.
And quickly.
And preferably without incurring massive damage to our discretionary funds.
We'll think of something, Capitaine.
If you're asking if I think they should be encouraged to nap, Capitaine...
It's more that I was wondering if our rigorous drill schedule has begun to impact their productivity.
Léopard, we should be at our destination soon. The crew was told to be at their stations two hours prior to our arrival for last minute equipment inspections.
Oui, Capitaine. But it looks like our path leads to an uninvited guest.
More Morganas? I'm really not in the mood.
No one ever is, Capitaine.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: You did great, Léopard. I hope we're still able to arrive at our destination on time...
Great win, Léopard. I'm confident we should arrive as planned.
It looks like our equipment could use a quick wipe down. Make sure the crew sees to that before our arrival.

Fields.DialogueText: Merci. You seem rather... anxious, Capitaine. Are you nervous about your meeting?
Merci, Capitaine. And are you sure you're confident? You sound a little nervous.
D'accord, Capitaine. But there's no reason to be nervous before your meeting.
I'm not nervous. I'm exhausted, my bunk smells like rotting meat, and I've been pulled off regular patrol to explain to a contre-amiral how Morgana Mist works - again - but I'm not nervous.
Eh, bien. I stand corrected.
Sorry if that was brusque. Has there been any word on the replacement bunks?
They should be waiting for us at port, Capitaine. Some assembly will be required, but...
That's fine. This makes this whole detour worthwhile.
We all do, from time to time. Now for a favor... if your time in Brest allows, would you be kind enough to bring me a bottle of Hors d'Age?
Armagnac? You have expensive taste!
Merci, Capitaine.
Actually... send someone to disassemble my current bunk. If I'm going to give a lecture on the mists, we might as well let the admiral smell them at their worst.
C'est juste cruel, Capitaine.
I have my moments.
But, sure - I'll do my best. I'll be glad to have something other than Morgana stink to think about.
How were early morning drills, Léopard? You seem to be in deep contemplation.
Je n'ai aucune plainte. The crew is sleeping well and everyone's in decent spirits.
Still, I can't help but think our drills could be more effective...

Fields.MenuText: More effective? I'm not sure what the crew will think about that.
How would you do that? From my view, they're well-designed and efficiently executed as is.
I admire your determination to always improve.

Fields.DialogueText: No need to worry, Capitaine. The crew knows my drills are tough but fair. And I have a plan to make them even better.
As always, you flatter me, Capitaine... but I do believe I have a plan.
Oh, anything and everything can be refined, and I have just the ticket.
Well, let's hear what you've come up with...
The crewmen have their drills memorized, no doubt about that. But I'd like to see their movements become more fluid.
Interesting, Léopard... what do you think would help?
Music. I believe if music were to be played while we performed drills, it would increase their morale.
I don't see any reason why we can't try it.
Wonderful, Capitaine. One last thing... the French crew members have spoken numerous times about Edith Piaf...
You're welcome to use her music for the drills, Léopard.
Capitaine, merci. Your support means a great deal to me.
And your ideas are just as important to me. Though... right now it may be your guns that we need most.
@BATTLE
The new bunks seem to have been worth the hassle, then. Good.
Get to your stations!
@BATTLE
Capitaine, I've noticed that, while music has helped our crew become more coordinated, it hasn't done as much as I'd hoped to improve their morale.

Fields.MenuText: There's really only so much you can do to make drills fun, you know.
I assume you have a plan in mind?
Hmm... I can't say that I've noticed.

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, but the ship is so dreary. The colors are drab and aren't meant to provide solace to those living aboard...
Yes. I was hoping to furnish the ship to offer the crew a bit of encouragement.
I have. And I believe a few furnishments and little more color on board would do the crew good.
We don't have the funds to do much, but if you were able to work within our means...
Ah, oui, Capitaine. Forgive me... I am working out the details as we speak. But, out of curiosity, what do you think about flowers?
I take it you mean more than just a single bouquet.
Well, I was thinking gardenias would be a nice touch to the ship. The scent is fragrant and you cannot pass by without admiring their silky white petals.
I'm not convinced, Léopard.
You must think outside of the box, Capitaine. They are just flowers, but the pleasant scent and touch of color could bring hope back to the crew.
Really?
That's the spirit, Capitaine!
Heh. This will be interesting.
And if we sail into climates where we can't keep them healthy and colorful? What does it mean for morale if you're staring at dead plants every time the Morganas give you room to breathe?
I... think it's within my power to keep that from happening, Capitaine. To protect the life onboard, even if it's flora.
Well, then, as far as I'm concerned it's fully justified as an experiment. Make it happen.
You'll need to place them very carefully - crew efficiency's in a good place right now, and I don't want that complicated.
Bien sûr! I'll get started immediately!
Hmm... oui, oui. I think that's exactly what I'm looking for...
Brochures? Manuals? The faint smell of armagnac? Oh, Léopard... you aren't? You are. Yes, you are.
What? I love my personal gear, but you know... sometimes you must part with what you have in order to welcome something better.

Fields.MenuText: What is it this time? You go through so much equipment, it's difficult to keep track of it all.
Here we go again, Léopard... should I expect a complete overhaul?

Fields.DialogueText: Capitaine, don't sound so negative. Change provokes growth, you know. It's for the benefit of myself and the ship.
In war, we must be flexible. That includes equipment.
Well, your equipment research will have to wait until later. Morganas are approaching.
Perhaps the perfect weapon will come to mind while we're in the thick of it.
@BATTLE

Listen, whatever it is you're shopping for - as long as we're talking supplemental orders for human-scale use rather than replacements for the Modèle 1919s - is going to be fine. I trust your judgment.
Merci, Capitaine. I will leave the paperwork on your desk.
That is among my least favorite sentences, you know.
If it would make your life easier, I could just forge your signature on all my future purchases...
I always like it when we survive.
Heh.
Your thoughtfulness is appreciated, but... no.
Vous ne pouvez pas reprocher à une fille de demander.

Fields.MenuText: Or you can stow it all in a barge and tow it behind you until you need it again.

Fields.DialogueText: Really?
No.
Anyway, I'm afraid your equipment research will have to wait. Morganas are approaching.
I see that you've been spending time by yourself and writing in your journal, Léopard.
Eh, oui? Have you been watching me, sir?
I just noticed, nothing more. I saw you writing... leaning against the gun and then dozing off. You've done that several times this week.
Not several times... maybe four or five? Since we are on the subject, my bottle of ink is nearly gone. Would you have any left, were I to need it?
Have you checked the ship's supplies? I would think we'd have gallons.
Actually, Capitaine, we had to trade the bulk of our supply to get the new bunks.
Right. I'll put in an order for more. Care to request a color?
Oh, Capitaine, if I were to choose a color out of pure imagination... green. It would be green.
Okay, let me rephrase that - care to request a color that won't raise too many eyebrows back at Command?
If a more sensible color would make things easier... blue would be just as beautiful.
I'll see what I can do.
Merci, Capitaine.
Now... if you'd care to repay me by sinking a few Morganas?
@BATTLE
Oh, son of a...
Get to your stations!
@BATTLE
Before I get distracted by clean-up - I *am* impressed, Léopard. The crew's performance in that battle was exceptional.
I agree, Capitaine. But we must not assume this is our best. We have much room for improvement.

Fields.MenuText: Heh. Of course, Léopard. But I can't help but admire our growth.
Don't push yourself or the crew too hard. Everyone needs rest to stay at their best.
Are you all right? You seem a little tense.

Fields.DialogueText: I apologize for my attitude, Capitaine. I've had quite a bit on my mind...
Bien sûr, Capitaine. I'm sorry, I spoke without thinking.
I'm sorry, Capitaine. My words escaped me without thought...
Relax. You have nothing to apologize for.
I don't think this should be outrageous, though. I've heard rumors of a book, said to be of Chinese origin.
Can you read Chinese?
I don't need to - it was translated into French in the 18th century.
We must have the Art of War in the library. I wouldn't have traded that away without remembering.
Would it not be too much trouble?
Not at all.
I knew you would understand. Merci, Capitaine.
Of course.
Unless you're about to ask me for something really outrageous...
Moi?
Vous.
... You know me too well.
Ah. Sun Tzu?
I don't know the correct pronunciation, but I think so. "Art de la guerre."
That said, would you like a copy of your own? It's a book that lends itself to annotation...
What's this?
Léopard, this looks like a shopping list for a party. I don't remember hearing about this...
Oh. I would have informed you, Capitaine. But then I decided against it, since I wanted you to have a formal invitation.

Fields.MenuText: Léopard. You know very well this is stepping on the line... this is not acceptable.
You know you can't do whatever please on board without my permission, Léopard. Others will assume they can do the same.
While I appreciate the thought, all party ideas really need to be run by me first.

Fields.DialogueText: I-I-I'm sorry, Capitaine. I have disappointed you. It was not my intent. I shouldn't have let myself get carried away.
Oh... of course, Capitaine. I didn't think. My apologies.
I knew I should have gone with my first instinct. I'm sorry, Capitaine.
Before you apologize, let me just get one thing clear - is this something you're just planning in your own free time, or is this something you've already initiated without...
Belly dancers! There will be belly dancers. A comrade knew someone who knew someone who knew a belly dancer, and she and her friends have tentatively agreed to perform for us.
*sigh*
Oui. And they're willing to teach us some moves as well. Isn't that great? I can use the moves as warm-ups to our drills!
I'm not sure about that. Still, I'm sure the crew will appreciate the chance to unwind.
Formidable! We shall carry out the plans, then... right, Capitaine? And would you like to receive a formal invitation?
Oh, I wouldn't miss it for the world.
@BATTLE
So, what's on the list? Drinks and hors d'oeuvres, streamers in gold, and... what?!
Non, non, non - just planning! I've corresponded with a few people, but I wouldn't commit to anything without your permission!
Okay. Then my attitude is one of curiosity rather than earth-shaking outrage.
Have they, now?
Only with your permission!
... I feel like getting you a copy of The Art of War might have been a mistake. I know a trap when I see one.
Belly dancers, huh?
Besides, you might need a bouncer.
What was that?!
C'était quoi? I didn't see anything. Should I be alarmed?

Fields.MenuText: It will show itself again... just wait for it.
Once you see it, you will be.
Oh, how did you miss it, Léopard? Wait... just wait... it will be back.

Fields.DialogueText: Is it a ghost? Gum on the floor that needs to be cleaned up? Out with it, Capitaine!
Well, it isn't nice keeping me in suspense.
You're making me nervous, Capitaine. How about we both inhale and exhale, and then you tell me what it was you saw.
There it is again!
... A mouse?
Or the world's tiniest Morgana.
And here I was, thinking death had come to visit. A mouse, Capitaine? Really?
This will have to wait. Morganas headed this direction, port-side.
What a convenient distraction.
@BATTLE
All right... great work out there, everyone. Léopard, your drills with the music must be working. The crew moved gracefully out there.
Thank you, Capitaine... but did you forget about your little friend?
Since you're so enamored with the little guy, why don't you capture it?
Bien sûr! All you had to do was ask.
Capitaine? Is it all right if I... keep it?
Seriously?
Please? Oh, please.
... Only if you keep it contained and fed.
Thank you, Capitaine! I will name her Sous-valu.
Of course. And what a fitting name, Léopard.
Shush.
Oh, don't look so incredulous. And, wait, what happened to the cat?
Lynx? I gave her to her namesake in the end. It seemed like the sisterly thing to do.
Or you didn't want the competition.
Hang on.
Get to your stations!
@BATTLE
Capitaine? I have an idea.

Fields.MenuText: When do you rest that mind of yours, Léopard? You can't always be thinking.
Of course you do. Why don't you put your glass of ice water down and tell me?

Fields.DialogueText: My idea is to mark the places we've been so far... I think it would be a great way to reflect.
I would like to see all of our ventures mapped. It would be a wonderful reminder of where we've been and what we've battled through together.
I've no objections, Léopard. How would you like to do it?
Well, I was initially thinking a flat map would do, but that's too easy. Not to mention, a little boring.
So, you'd like to place markers on a globe?
Yes! Have I ever told you how much appreciate your ability to pick up on what I am thinking?
Heh. You've mentioned it on occasion.
A globe shouldn't be a problem. It would suit us well to have one on board along with our maps. Carry on now, before you are late for drills.
Of course, right. Merci beaucoup, Capitaine!

Fields.MenuText: ... How much will it cost us?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, nothing! Or nearly nothing. It's more of an activity than a purchase.
You have my attention.
Do you know anything about taking photos, Capitaine? Wouldn't it be wonderful to add a photograph here and there in your daily log?
I don't think my log has room, but it's nice to have photos around. What sort of subjects did you have in mind?
Oh, I don't know... anything and everything. Our lives are quite interesting, n'est-ce pas?

Fields.MenuText: I'd agree! We're engaged in an epic fight against the forces of evil, after all.
This paperwork I've been trying to complete for weeks now would say differently.

Fields.DialogueText: Now, just picture those fights immortalized in black and white!
I'm sure, with the right angle and lighting, I could even make paperwork look interesting.
It sounds like you've put some thought into this topic...
Well, not as much as you think. I've just been playing around with the idea...
Have you heard of the Parvo camera? No? Well, I think we can look into bringing one of those on board.
Oh, how wonderful! It doesn't matter what kind of camera... just as long as it can take photos. Merci, Capitaine. The crew will be thrilled, I'm sure.
I'm looking forward to seeing what you and the crew capture. Now, I need to get back to my endless mountain of paperwork.
Of course! Merci beaucoup, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
With a little bit of luck we can even get it before your party. Though I'm not sure we need pictures of belly dancers getting back to the admirals...

Fields.MenuText: Especially the terrifying bits.

Fields.DialogueText: Oui! Now, just picture those terrifying bits immortalized in black and white!
Ha!
Mmm. What's that smell? Where are we? Casablanca?
Yes, Léopard - though I can't smell what you're smelling. It's good, I take it?
Oh, it is. I must learn what that scent is...
Capitaine! Enemies spotted. Starboard.
Good eyes, Léopard.
@BATTLE
Back to what we were talking about, Léopard - I'm guessing you were smelling some combination of Moroccan spices. Saffron, ginger, maybe cumin...
I'd love to try it all!
Y'know, you haven't asked for any spices lately. Are you still collecting them?
Oh! Oui, bien sûr! We've just been so busy that I haven't had much time to track new spices down.

Fields.MenuText: Would you like to add a Moroccan selection to your collection?
Well, if you don't want me to shop around in Casablanca...
Well, then - a vat of Moroccan cinnamon will be just the thing to start the collection anew.

Fields.DialogueText: You truly are a wonderful friend, Capitaine. I don't know how I could repay you for your constant kindness.
Of course I want you to! Don't tease me so, Capitaine.
I like the way you think, sir.
Get to your stations! Dépêchez-vous!
@BATTLE
Isn't this gorgeous? It's as if our battle was painted onto the sky... a reflection, almost. The clouds have taken such striking shapes...

Fields.MenuText: That was quite poetic of you, Léopard.
I'm the sort to keep my eyes on the water, quite frankly.

Fields.DialogueText: Haha, you think? Such sights inspire poetry in many people, I'd wager.
But you miss so much of the world that way, Capitaine.
So. How are you doing, Léopard? Any problems I should be aware of?
Rien. Nothing at all, Capitaine. I feel all is perfect, now. Sitting here with a good friend, enjoying the world following a hard-fought battle.
I understand... it's good to find these moments of tranquility, to break up the tension of this war.
We have to do so purposefully. Otherwise, the stress will overwhelm us, sooner or later.
Nah. Not you. I know when things are at their worst, you'll be out there roping in belly dancers to keep the rest of us going.
No rope involved, Capitaine.

Fields.MenuText: That one over there looks like a giant stack of paperwork.

Fields.DialogueText: Ha! Being capitaine is hard on you, isn't it?
Well, I'm muddling through.
I can't put my finger on it... I've thought about it for days and I just don't know what it is...
Are you all right, Léopard? You're pacing back and forth like a crazed person and talking to yourself out loud.
Je ne sais pas - that's the thing. Maybe you can help me, Capitaine. It started days ago... I had an idea about upgrading something... and never noted it. And now I've forgotten...
Is it part of your armament? Your upgrading typically involves your equipment...
Oh, I wish it were that simple. I've considered every conceivable armament upgrade, all to no avail...
*ALARM*
I'm sorry, Léopard... but I need you to focus some of that energy toward what's ahead.
Formidable. Maybe this will help me remember what I had in mind. Let's go!
@BATTLE
So... did it work? I'm guessing no, you don't look satisfied.
Non, Capitaine... I'm tired and I can't think straight. I'm going to lay down. Will you do me a favor, please?
Past experience would suggest I will.
Will you find me a pair of sunglasses? A bug-eyed pair to hide the dark circles I bare as a result of my truant mind.
I'll get you sunglasses, but you will only receive them once that attitude passes. You shouldn't be so hard on yourself. Now, get some sleep.
Merci, Capitaine. Au revoir...
I'm glad your uniform has gotten better at keeping out the cold. I wish I could say the same for mine.
They fight in any weather, Capitaine... but I agree. Ready.
@BATTLE
Léopard, how would you feel about putting that spice collection to good use?
You want something that will really fill everyone up, do you?
What do you think about a soup, Capitaine? We can include as much meat as we want, it will surely stick to the bones of the crew, and - oui - I have a number of spices we could add.
That's a perfect idea. I'm sure the crew will be delighted.
I'll head to the galley immediately and we'll work something out.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you, Léopard! As always, you're such a help.

Fields.DialogueText: Glad to be of service!
You'd think these Morganas would let up.
Capitaine?
If you're saving it all for your party, I understand - but I can't help but think that the crew could do with a happy surprise at dinner tonight.

Fields.MenuText: Be as quick as you can. I'm hungry.

Fields.DialogueText: Do what I do! Hide snacks around the ship!
... That explains the mouse.

Fields.MenuText: Glad to see you're feeling better, by the way.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm, but how much onion do we have...
Heh.
Léopard, will you do me a favor?
Of course.
I need a message sent, but I can't find Lieutenant Frances.
What do you need me to do?

Fields.MenuText: Would you mind locating Frances?
Point me to the nearest code book? I can figure the rest out on my own.
Would you mind finding someone to encrypt this message and get it out?

Fields.DialogueText: I can do that! I saw him just a few minutes ago.
Oh, wait! That's Lieutenant Frances down there, isn't it? I'll go fetch him.
I'll do you one better. I just saw Lieutenant Frances. I'll get him.
Fantastic. Thank you, Léopard.
Sorry, Captain! Nature called! You have something for me?
Right here. Thank you, Lieutenant.
You know, Frances has told me about a dessert that I must try... he called it a chocolate truffle.
He told you that in the three seconds it took you to get him here? The man's efficient, I'll give him that.
Well... peut-être. It does sound like a delight - a delight that I have never experienced.
For retrieving Lieutenant Frances with such haste, I will see whether we can arrange for a few truffles to be brought aboard, Léopard.
You'll need to pay for them yourself, though. If I pay for chocolate for you, I have to pay for chocolate for everyone.
Bien sûr, Capitaine. I can't wait. Perhaps I'll even share a piece with you.
*ALARM*
Sounds as if the Morganas don't want to be left out of the chocolate-related festivities.
Évidemment.
@BATTLE
Don't change the subject.
Sorry. I do believe you were about to ask for food.
Capitaine. Oh, Capitaine... I have the greatest idea.
What's going on?
I rushed all the way here once drills came to an end... and after I spoke to a comrade...

Fields.MenuText: You came up with the greatest idea...
All right, Léopard. Must we do this tango every time you've made some great discovery?
You rushed here? Couldn't you just... blip?

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly!
Please, just listen. It is the greatest idea. One of my best, I assure you.
"Blip?" Capitaine, where is the drama in a "blip?" Where is the sense of excitement?
I spoke to my comrade, and she says there's painter on board. A crew member.
So, before his life as a sailor, he was a painter? That's a wonderful thing to know, but what was your idea? You want him to paint the ship?
Hah! Well, yes and no. He's not that kind of painter... he is an artist.
Oh... I see. And you want him to paint a portrait of the ship?
Oui. And the crew. I'd work out the details with him, but I think a large portrait would be a great touch to the ship.
How do you suppose he'd paint himself in?
Oh, he knows what he looks like... he'll figure it out. That's what artists do.
Heh, I suppose it is. Very well, as long as it doesn't interfere with anyone's duties, I grant you permission to lead the project.
I'll go track him down. Merci, merci...
@BATTLE
I'm just saying, if I could teleport...
Non, non, non. You have more flair than you give yourself credit for.
... I'll buy that.
Please, continue.
... I'm guessing that camera isn't going to see as much use as I originally expected, then.
Capitaine! We have a problem heeeere!
What is it? Why are you screaming?
The crew found a beehive in stowage. We have more than a few bee stings on our hands.
... Of course we do.
One of the food containers had it tucked in with the contents.
Right. We need to isolate the hive and apply smoke to it. The bees will then be tame enough to be transported, beehive and all, elsewhere.
Good idea!
Lieutenant Frances!
Yes, sir?
We need to smoke out and transport the bees on the ship. Form a team, communicate those instructions to them, and carry the plan out. Understand?
... But I was just going to the radio room.
Get to it!
Yes, Captain.
*ALARM*
Wonderful.
@BATTLE
The matter has been taken care of, Captain. The crew sent me with this bottle of honey from the small hive. No one really wanted it after breathing in all the smoke.
Thank you, Frances. I do appreciate the effort - make sure any stings are seen to by sick bay.
Yes, sir. Of course.
Léopard, have you had honey before?
I have, but not fresh off of the hive. Intriguing...
Would you like to have this jar of honey? I've no need for it.
Why, oui... I would love to add it to green mint tea.
Perfect. Consider it yours.
Is there an explanation, or...?
Are you allergic to bees?
No.
Then your leadership skills are required elsewhere.
Get to your stations! Vite!
@BATTLE
Capitaine... I don't think our chronometer is reading accurately. It's actually quite a bit off from what the quintant is showing.
Hmm... I see. Yeah, it looks like we need to get it repaired. I'll call...
How about we replace it with a new one, instead?

Fields.MenuText: Well, it is something that we need to work correctly. Did a particular chronometer catch your fancy?
You've been planning this for a while, haven't you?

Fields.DialogueText: Actually, no... I just thought it was a great opportunity.
Peut-être...
Go ahead, research different chronometers, identify the pros and cons of repairing versus replacing.
Perfect, Capitaine. I'll get right on it.
Once you've finished, bring me your findings. We'll figure out where to go from there.
Sounds good to me.

Fields.MenuText: It's not in *that* bad shape.

Fields.DialogueText: Mais...
*sigh*
Lieutenant Sande, are all of the chairs prepped and ready?
Yes, Léopard. The snack table has been set up and is waiting for the kitchen crew to put out the foods and drinks.
And the equipment and movie? That is the most important detail... imagine if we had everything else and the main event was not available.
Yes, Léopard. The movie has been taken care of. Now if you'll excuse me, I have just a few last minute checks to make.
Oh, oui. Merci beacoup, Lieutenant Sande. You've done a great job.
Capitaine, are you ready? Come on... I'm sure it isn't that bad.

Fields.MenuText: I look like I belong in a window display.
Why are we dressing up? I look foolish.
Bad, hell. I look fantastic.

Fields.DialogueText: And what's wrong with that, Capitaine? The whole crew is dressing up.
You'll look just like everyone else. I'm sure everyone will keep their eyes on the film and not on your formal wear.
And you're so modest, too!
Here. Go ahead and laugh. You might as well do it now, before the showing.
Capitaine... you look wonderful. And your hair... I love it.
You are very gracious.
*ALARM*
Ugh. Not nowwww... How annoying. Capitaine, Morganas.
Ha, ha... well, it's not a party without Morganas. Ready?
Let's get it over with... the one night I was trying to be on time.
@BATTLE
Thank you for allowing me to assist. I'll see you at the party.
You think "Fric-Frac" is a bigger draw than the dancers, ma'am?
Dancers are just people! "Fric-Frac" is cinema, Sande! Cinema!
Now, is it ready?
Heh.
So, I hear you got bored with the belly dancers?
I'm not bored with them. But they weren't a surprise! The film is a surprise!
What are you looking at, Léopard?
... Just ahead. I'm looking for things floating in the water.
That's not what a quintant is for, Léopard... what you need are binoculars.
It may not be what it is for, but it does the work nonetheless.

Fields.MenuText: It may - and yet, I'm asking you to use the quintant as it was made to be used.

Fields.DialogueText: Very well. Comme vous le souhaitez.
Thank you.
Do you mind if I use yours?
My what?
Your binoculars! You know, those things dangling around your neck.
Heh. Of course. Here.
Merci!
Have you spotted something interesting out there?
Léopard?
*sigh*
Morganas?
I'm afraid so.
Just our luck.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: Fair enough, I suppose.

Fields.DialogueText: ... Mais vous avez raison. They're not ideal.

Fields.MenuText: Do you actually mean that, or are you just being stubborn?

Fields.DialogueText: Don't give me that look. It's a fair question.
*sigh*
Non. They're not ideal.
How have drills been going, Léopard? I see great improvement in the crew's approach.
There are days when it is exhausting, but I firmly believe all the hard work is paying off.
After all, if the capitaine notices, you must be doing something right, right?

Fields.MenuText: Heh. I think my opinion would be too biased to have any footing here, Léopard.
Without a doubt.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, you're such a tease, Capitaine.
I knew it!
Me? It must be my soap. There was a delivery mix-up, which means I'm now cleaning up with Savon eau de rose, rosewater soap.
Mmm, I love it. Do you suppose one could buy rosewater? I would love to splash my skin with it.
I see some at port from time to time. You want me to find you some next time we're at dock?
Please, Capitaine. Thank you so much.
*ALARM*
You know, I thought I had caught the scent of something putrid.
How pleasant. Are you ready?
Always, Capitaine.
@BATTLE
You smell really good, by the way. Why is that?
Now, tell me what scent you are using. It's light but very pleasant.

Fields.MenuText: I mean, I'd notice if they set the deck on fire, too.

Fields.DialogueText: Why is there so much clutter strewn about the galley?
Léopard!
Oui? I'm a little busy...
What is this mess? A basket of eggs, onions, potatoes... I almost fell trying to navigate through it all.
You forgot about my pots and pans. I am making you a dish. I've been craving this for quite some time now, and today is the day.

Fields.MenuText: I have no idea what you're making...
I'd be a shame if I broke my neck tripping over your mess before I had the chance to taste this mysterious dish.
Clearly.

Fields.DialogueText: You ought to use a little imagination, then.
All right, all right, message received. I'll pick up after myself.
Feeling somewhat sardonic today, are you, Capitaine?
Okay, okay. Tell me what you're making. I'll admit, I am rather hungry...
Wonderful. I am preparing to make you... an omelet.
It's been some time since I had a good omelet. Would you like some help?
No, no, no... I am cooking for you. But before I start...
*ALARM*
... Bien sûr.
Heh. Their timing is something... you think they caught wind of your plans?
Maybe, maybe not. Either way, they'll have egg on their face once I'm done with them.
@BATTLE
Get to your stations!
@BATTLE
The sky is so clear today, Capitaine. You know what I wish we had...

Fields.MenuText: What's that, Léopard?
Candy, tea, and spices?
You want the sky? I can't get you the sky, Léopard.

Fields.DialogueText: It flies, it's big, and it has a tail...
Not quite. It can be many colors, but it also flies.
You're the sort who could accomplish anything you set your mind to, I think. But in this case, I don't require the sky. Only something that flies in it.
Heh, a kite?
A kite! Wouldn't that be marvelous? Are there kites shaped as ships? I would like a kite that looks like our ship...
I'm not sure... I don't think I've seen one before.
Well, I am in no rush. But if you do see one, please let me know. I must have one.
I will, Léopard. Maybe I'll get a couple. The crew is bound to enjoy them as well.
How wonderful. Thank you, Capitaine.
You will you teach me how to fly it, won't you? I've never flown one before.
Of course, Léopard. Maybe we'll both learn a thing or two.
